questions.question_text:
A company wants to implement a wireless infrastructure on its campus to meet the needs of its BYOD initiative. The company has users with legacy devices and wants to accommodate them while delivering speed to other users who have modern systems.
Which of the following standards BEST fits these requirements?

comments.content: That's what I was thinking, considering N supports both frequencies.

discussion.content: shouldn't 802.11n be an option here .... since the question speaks of both legacy and modern devices
I had this exact question in the exam and one of the options was 802.11 n
n supports both 2.4 and 5 ghz ranges. some devices can only operate in wireless mode in either a 2.4 or ghz range. 802.11n will allow both modern and old devices to be used.
Based on the comments, the answer has been changed to include 802.11n
"Best" fits the requirements will be answer B. These questions aren't going to always make sense. You have to choose from the given options.
Im looking at the comments here. Lol

802.11ac

The newest generation of Wi-Fi signaling in popular use, 802.11ac utilizes dual band wireless technology, supporting simultaneous connections on both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz Wi-Fi bands. 802.11ac offers backward compatibility to 802.11b/g/n and bandwidth rated up to 1300 Mbps on the 5 GHz band plus up to 450 Mbps on 2.4 GHz.

The answer is D. 802.11g is 54mhz, which is faster than 11b. 11a only supports 5Ghz. 11ac only supports 5Ghz. Thus, 11g is the best choice since you can downgrade the 5Ghz to 2.4Ghz (legacy devices) and still have a better speed than 11b.

comments.content: Yes, but 11n is not a choice, so the best choice is 11g.

discussion.content:
IEEE 802.11ac === 5GHz BAND.
IEEE 802.11n === 2.4GHz and 5GHz band.
I am looking for an N option
Fact! the correct answer should be 802.11 n

comments.content:
Is 802.11 AC dual band?
Most 802.11ac devices available now support dual band and 3x3 (three antennas and three streams). Supporting dual band allows the AP to broadcast both a 2.4GHz and 5GHz Wi-Fi network.
- extracted Next-Gen 802.11ac Wi-Fi for Dummies

discussion.content:
Is 802.11 AC dual band?
Most 802.11ac devices available now support dual band and 3x3 (three antennas and three streams). Supporting dual band allows the AP to broadcast both a 2.4GHz and 5GHz Wi-Fi network.

choices.A: Use a secure SSH connection over the WAN link.
choices.D: Configure a DSL router to the console port.
choices.C: Implement a modem on the AUX port.
choices.B: Telnet into the router over the company VPN.

discussion.content:
AUX port - backup console port - using dial-up 
Auxiliary Port (AUX Port) allows a direct, non-network connection to the router, from a remote location. The Auxiliary Port (AUX Port) uses a connector type to which modems can plug into, which allows an administrator from a remote location to access the router like a console port.

console port - using terminal emulation

Correct me if I am mistaken, but this seems like an Out-of-Band management (OOB) technique to me. Remote connections that are solely hardware based. This is where Joe (Technician) is attempting to troubleshoot the router via the modem.

The purpose of the auxiliary port is for connecting to an external modem. Once configured, this modem can be used as a backup demand-dial connection to another location, or as a way to dial in to the router for troubleshooting purposes should regular connectivity fail. The answer is correct
why isn't this A?

comments.content: It says "implement" not "install." Maybe the modem was already there and he's using what's already there?

"Joe needs to reset the WAN connection settings". -> He wants permanent connection so WAN is no options here.

But how could he remotely install a modem..

questions.question_text:
Joe, a technician, is attempting to resolve an issue with an off-site router remotely. Joe needs to reset the WAN connection settings and wants to ensure he will have access to the router at all times to monitor the changes.
Which of the following solutions would BEST meet this goal?

The network support team is responsible for managing connections in a large, multipurpose venue where maintaining physical security is difficult. Implementing which of the following standards would BEST help to prevent unauthorized connections to the wired network?

discussion.content:
The IEEE standard 802.1X defines port-based security for wireless network
access control. As such, it offers a means of authentication and defines the
Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) over IEEE 802, which is often known
as EAP over LAN (EAPOL). The biggest benefit of using 802.1X is that the
access points and the switches do not need to do the authentication but instead
rely on the authentication server to do the work.

The question doesn't say that the utility companies device is connected to the residents personal home WiFi, therefore you should assume it wouldn't be on their network. No company would be stealing paid internet service from their customers.

comments.content: That would make more sense if the WAP was an 802.11b/g or n working at 2.4Ghz....the 5Ghz band (of the 802.11ac) shouldn't be prone to interference...But what do I know? the smar reader could be working on the 5Ghz as well...

discussion.content: i assume C. interference...

I think it's C. From an article:
"The smart meters use the unlicensed 2.4GHz frequency band. So if a Wi-Fi router or other device, overlaps on the same channel, there can be some interference, according to Central Maine Power. The problem can be addressed by moving devices away from the smart meter or changing the channel that electronics use, the utility says in its smart meter FAQ."

its not possible for (C) to be the answer i did some research and No. Smart meters use an entirely separate, wireless system. You don't need Wi-Fi in your home for it to work and it won't use your Wi-Fi if you have it. so how can this (C) be the right answer it wont affect home wireless because it doesn't use wifi so it cant affect wireless losing connectivity

I think the correct answer is (D) only because when it says company has installed a wireless device that was when the issue with 802.11ac home wireless intermittently loses connectivity when the device was installed DDOS attacks is focused on disabling the continuity of communication of devices connected to a network, affecting the switched flow tables, data on a network, bandwidth and latency (D) makes so much sense then the other options but this is just my opinion !!!
throttling and additional data being send would only slow down, it wouldn't disconnect right ? Therefore i will go with C.
smart meter
In order to keep your sanity with these questions, perform a process of elimination. The last answer standing is the one, regardless of how improbable it sounds.
How can additional data being transferred cause an AP to lose connectivity?
"Most likely" type of questions aren't always going to make sense. They want you to eliminate from the best answer.
No way this is B. How could additional data result in loosing connection.
15 minutes, twice a day??? How much data could they possibly be transferring? I've completed online backups faster than that.

choices.A: The utility company throttles power during peak hours.
choices.B: There is additional data being transferred over the wireless network.
choices.C: There is interference with the smart reader.
choices.D: An IoT device is causing a DoS attack on the wireless network.

questions.question_text:
A utility company has installed a wireless device at a residence that allows the company to view power consumption online. The resident reports the 802.11ac home wireless intermittently loses connectivity for about 15 minutes twice a day.
Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

A technician has been asked to install biometric controls at the entrance of a new datacenter. Which of the following would be appropriate authentication methods to meet this requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: biometrics - think of biology so then think of human body, retina - eye - finger print - finger. these types of questions are literally free points when you understand what they're asking for.
